channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description: @PFemme2 @JuliaDavisNews @oneunderscore__ Russia has always had limited access to trade w/o friendly regimes in regions today known as Belarus and Ukraine. If they lose Ukraine, eventually they’ll lose #Georgia, and then #Tatarstan, and by then no one will be buying gas anymore; #Moscovy will be left with the fur trade. https://t.co/i691bTGCN8
@StephenElsberry @PFemme2 @JuliaDavisNews @oneunderscore__ … or for Ukraine to shut off existing lines from Russia to Europe. https://t.co/1N3JxU0ql3
@igorsushko Open-source tool to contact random Russians via telephone, SMS, WhatsApp messages, or e-mail: https://t.co/KJ5QLxQrGj https://t.co/unbljLLVd9
@flobo09 Are they just using Edge #WebView in file explorer? Apparently it’s just a prototype operating system…

@stevecalamia @horsemankukka @JosephPolitano People tend to have fairly narrow viewing horizons, too. Look at debates a region has (e.g. health care policy debates) and compare how much time they spend arguing over hypotheticals and projections vs. how little detailed discourse there is about working models elsewhere.
@schneierblog The tweet referred to by the blog: https://t.co/lmSjlXmVtF

@dangerwookie @igorsushko Yes to the fear part, but contrasting that, this letter says that they’re not expecting the ‘west’ to react with force, but to capitulate. Also, an earlier letter mentioned a crack-down at the #FSB and that the author was exhausted and burnt out. Lots of variables.

@dangerwookie @igorsushko Yeah, he didn’t explain until the following letter, but I imagine the recipient (with whom he has had a long-running correspondence) could see from context that these were not the analyst’s own thoughts but rather the analyst retelling of a plan being formulated inside the FSB.

@Glaukopos @IronMonkeeMN @Aviation_Intel @TrentTelenko @NATO If Putin wanted war with @NATO, he would attack @NATO. He clearly does not. The #UkraineWar is going to have long-lasting consequences for #Russia. War with @NATO would be worse for them. So no, the suggestion is to ‘bait’ the #Russians into (at least limited) deescalation.
@IronMonkeeMN @Glaukopos @Aviation_Intel @TrentTelenko @NATO I don’t disagree. It’s a smart move, and clearly one that Putin will yell about.

@Glaukopos @IronMonkeeMN @Aviation_Intel @TrentTelenko @NATO That’s what it _has_ meant in recent years, as a ‘term of art’. It doesn’t sound like _that_ kind of NFZ is being seriously discussed; the downsides are pretty darn clear. Perhaps we need different terminology to break out of past mindsets? (In future wars: airborne minefield) https://t.co/71HX59r0jU

@IronMonkeeMN @Aviation_Intel @TrentTelenko That’s the conceit, right? Putin has warned that @NATO firing first would start #WWIII. He either believes that or he doesn’t. - If he honestly does, wouldn’t he think that Russia would be initiating WWIII by firing on @NATO units first? - If he doesn’t, then it’s a bluff.
@IronMonkeeMN @Aviation_Intel @TrentTelenko Wait, who has been suggesting flying anything, manned or unmanned, _across the border into Russian airspace_?
@COUPSURE Gotcha. The majority of the river returns to near its original appearance in the third frame - did it all melt / flow away, except for immediately next to the bridge?

@oldblueglass @Aviation_Intel @gerrydogma Forces from @NATO / @coe / @UN can _get in the way_, and force #Russia to dare to take the first shot in an escalation of the theatre. Perhaps we should be thinking of this more like an aerial ‘naval #blockade’ or ‘freedom of navigation’ campaign than a traditional #NoFlyZone? https://t.co/71HX59r0jU
